ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 8: The instructor explained conceptual material clearly but went too fast and was disorganized.

5. There were a good amount of field trips, but they could have been better spaced throughout the semester. I know that some events were changed around or added last minute, but it's just something to keep in mind for the future. Spacing the trips allows for time to process and discuss each one individually.

Q1: The readings were often a little long and because we just had an open discussion about them there wasn't much motivation to read everything thoroughly. Perhaps inform us that it is or is not okay to skim certain readings and help us utilize our time best by pointing out sections of the text you would especially like us to focus on. Q7:I learned a lot from the Bridgeport field trip. The others not so much. Q8: There is a lot to cover and much of it is new for many people. A mre organized format to the class may be helpful for some people. I think it is okay to have a lot of brainstorming and discussion but make sure to hit home the important points and present them clearly. Q12: Besides feeling like the structure of the course was a little messy, I know I at least took away an understanding of designed experiemnts and resilience corridors.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips were great. Seeing real world examples of the materials brought up in the course really helped drive the concepts home.

The field trips were great and the class assignments asked students to try their hand at exactly what we discussed in class. The partnership with the architecture school was neat, but more of a time commitment than I initially realized. I know those meetings weren't mandatory, but they were enriching and it would be great if everyone could have attended most of them. Maybe all that could be made clearer in the syllabus or during the first class.
The discussions during class, applied concepts and field trips.
Being able to think creatively on the last assignment and greater exposure to GIS in a low pressure environment.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Needs better organization

Overall, the course needs organization. For example, I enjoyed interacting with the urbanism studio, but felt like the collaboration would need to be far more methodical in order for it to work. This could include an official first meeting between architecture and FES students that everyone is aware of and participates in, followed by several partially shared classes. Otherwise, there is too much confusion about the role FES students are playing in the studio and the extent of their involvement.

Keeping on time during class. We had a lot of time, yet we still were often unable to finish the prepared powerpoint or to have everyone share their project ideas thoroughly. It's okay if the arc of a class changes based on what is most engaging for students, but that doesn't mean we should stay beyond class time to finish up what is necessary.
I liked the connection to the architecture program. However, making their designs fit into our coarse could become a more solid aspect in the future.

The assignments could have been better-structured; students were supposed to be paired with studios from the School of Architecture, but there was very little communication as to whom we should contact and how. In general, communication of expectations was lacking throughout the course. Students did not receive grades on any of our assignments prior to the end of classes.
We need feedback on assignments before the next one is due.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It is a useful course in understanding the relationship between urban ecology and design
I am interested in the environmental challenges cities face.
I am interested in applied urban concepts. This course is directly related to my area of interest.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in building cities that have a strong ecological component.
To learn the tools and methods associated with urban ecology.
It sounded interesting and offered a new perspective on ecology, which is my main course of study.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes

The course exposed me to the language surrounding urban ecology, concepts in the field, and examples of work done in the field. I also learned how urban ecology has evolved overtime. These elements of the course met my expectations. However, I would have liked to develop a more thorough understanding of some of the concepts we learned.

I thought I would be learning more about Ecology in the city, but the differences between that and ecology of the city and urban ecology were discussed early on and I realized that the subject matter would be different than expected.
Yes.

Learned perhaps a little less of concrete material than I expected but there were a few key takeaways that were valuable and the overall exposure to the topic and the way architects think and function was valuable.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I thought the group projects were very useful. Need to integrate even more with architecture school.

Advantages: learning from my team mates. Mixing up teams to include architecture and FES students was beneficial and broadened my perspective. Disadvantages: Dealing with team dynamics. Some people are more engaged and contribute more than others. Managing team dynamics often requires just as much time as working on the assignment.

My partner and I had different backgrounds in terms of what we had studied and projects we had done in the past. Our strengths complemented each other, so I think we were able to learn from each other and produce a better project together than apart.
The advantages were sharing ideas and responsibility, however the disadvantages were that it was hard to find time to meet and the burden of work is not always equal.
Working in very small groups, having different ideas on how to approach assignments can make it very difficult to complete work with all students having equal input.
Some people were highly experienced while others were very new to the subject and the mixing of the two was not that well-done.
Figuring out new concepts together to help reinforce what we learned in class. The opportunity to brainstorm and think creatively with another person.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Good class if you are interested in design and integrating ecology into design.
Let go of any expectations and desires for orderliness. The class evolves and develops on a weekly basis and accepting this early on can alleviate frustration.

Recognize that the professor is a landscape architect and that there is a heavy design component to the class. Ecologists should not be intimidated away from taking this class because it is designed as in introduction.
Don't expect a typical class structure and be flexible with assignment types and due dates. If you can go with the flow than you should be okay.
